headline: Kimberly-Clark to acquire Tylenol maker Kenvue in $48.7 billion deal
summary: Kimberly-Clark is buying Tylenol maker Kenvue in an approximately $48.7 billion cash-and-stock deal, creating a massive consumer health goods company.

content.summary: Kimberly-Clark is buying Tylenol maker Kenvue in an approximately $48.7 billion cash-and-stock deal, creating a massive consumer health goods company.

headline: Kimberly-Clark to Buy Tylenol Maker Kenvue in $48.7 Billion Deal. Kimberly-Clark Stock Tanks.
summary: Kimberly-Clark  agreed to buy  Kenvue  in a cash-and-stock transaction that values the Tylenol maker  Kenvue  at an enterprise value of about $48.7 billion, including debt.  Under the terms of the deal, Kenvue shareholders will receive $21.01 a share, based on Kenvue’s closing price of $14.37 on Friday, the companies said.  At closing,  Kimberly-Clark  shareholders will own roughly 54% of the combined company, with current Kenvue shareholders owning the remaining 46%.

content.title: Kimberly-Clark to Buy Tylenol Maker Kenvue in $48.7 Billion Deal. Kimberly-Clark Stock Tanks.
content.summary: Kimberly-Clark  agreed to buy  Kenvue  in a cash-and-stock transaction that values the Tylenol maker  Kenvue  at an enterprise value of about $48.7 billion, including debt.  Under the terms of the deal, Kenvue shareholders will receive $21.01 a share, based on Kenvue’s closing price of $14.37 on Friday, the companies said.  At closing,  Kimberly-Clark  shareholders will own roughly 54% of the combined company, with current Kenvue shareholders owning the remaining 46%.

headline: Kenvue jumps 22% on $48.7 billion Kimberly-Clark merger deal
summary: Investing.com -- Shares in Kenvue soared over 22% in premarket trading Monday after the U.S. consumer health company reported better-than-expected earnings for the third quarter and announced it has reached a deal to be acquired by Kimberly-Clark for $48.7 billion.

content.title: Kenvue jumps 22% on $48.7 billion Kimberly-Clark merger deal
content.summary: Investing.com -- Shares in Kenvue soared over 22% in premarket trading Monday after the U.S. consumer health company reported better-than-expected earnings for the third quarter and announced it has reached a deal to be acquired by Kimberly-Clark for $48.7 billion.

headline: Kimberly-Clark to Buy Tylenol Maker Kenvue for More Than $40 Billion
summary: Kimberly-Clark  has agreed to buy  Kenvue  for more than $40 billion, combining the maker of Huggies diapers with the owner of Tylenol and other consumer healthcare products.  Kimberly-Clark’s share price fell around 16% ahead of the bell.  In the cash-and-stock deal, Kimberly-Clark will pay $21.01 a share, based on its closing price from Friday.

Kimberly-Clark’s share price fell around 16% ahead of the bell.  In the cash-and-stock deal, Kimberly-Clark will pay $21.01 a share, based on its closing price from Friday.

headline: Tylenol, Kleenex, Band-Aid and more put under one roof in $48.7 billion consumer brands deal
summary: Kimberly-Clark is buying Tylenol maker Kenvue in a cash and stock deal worth about $48.7 billion, creating a massive consumer health goods company.  Shareholders of Kimberly-Clark will own about 54% of the combined company.  Kenvue shareholders will own about 46%.

headline: Wall Street futures march higher as deal making takes spotlight from corporate earnings
summary: U.S. futures followed global markets higher on Monday ahead of another big week of corporate earnings reports but an absence of economic data as the U.S. government shutdown entered its second month.  Futures for the S&P 500 gained 0.3% before the bell, while Nasdaq futures advanced 0.6%.  Microsoft said it has entered into an approximately $9.7 billion cloud services contract with artificial intelligence cloud service provider IREN that will give it access to some of Nvidia’s chips.

content.title: Wall Street futures march higher as deal making takes spotlight from corporate earnings
content.summary: U.S. futures followed global markets higher on Monday ahead of another big week of corporate earnings reports but an absence of economic data as the U.S. government shutdown entered its second month.  Futures for the S&P 500 gained 0.3% before the bell, while Nasdaq futures advanced 0.6%.  Microsoft said it has entered into an approximately $9.7 billion cloud services contract with artificial intelligence cloud service provider IREN that will give it access to some of Nvidia’s chips.

headline: Is the End of the Line Near for Kenvue?
summary: The purchase of Kenvue by Kimberly-Clark announced Monday would mark the close of a short, rocky term of independence for the Tylenol maker, which was spun off from Johnson & Johnson in 2023.  Kenvue shares have been under pressure since President Trump’s warning that acetaminophen—the active ingredient in Tylenol—is a potential cause of autism.  Kenvue has called the claims baseless.

headline: Kimberly-Clark bets $40 billion on Kenvue despite Tylenol controversy
summary:
STORY: :: Kimberly-Clark

Kimberly-Clarke is betting big on the maker of Tylenol, announcing it will acquire parent company Kenvue for more than $40 billion... marking the largest buyout ever among the U.S. consumer goods industry.

The historic deal comes after U.S. President Donald Trump made remarks about the painkiller at the White House in September, citing unproven claims linking Tylenol use during pregnancy to autism in children.

:: September 22, 2025

UPSOUND US PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP: “Don't take Tylenol. Don't take it. If you just can't, I mean, fight like hell not to take it."

Shares of Tylenol-parent Kenvue - which also owns Band-Aid and Neutrogena - soared as much as 19% after the deal's announcement, while buyer Kimberly-Clark's shares tumbled about 14%.

:: File

Kenvue, which was spun off from Johnson & Johnson in 2023, has struggled for months with weak demand.

The company fired its CEO in July and said it was undergoing a strategic review of its assets.

Investor concern over Monday's merger announcement may stem in part from Kenvue's potential legal exposure to private lawsuits alleging it hid Tylenol's supposed link to autism in children.

U.S. sales of Tylenol fell 11% between September 20 and October 4 after Trump's remarks, according to a BNP Paribas analyst note last month.

:: Kimberly-Clark

But the merger does give Kimberly-Clark access to Kenvue's vast portfolio of brands - which also include Aveeno and Neutrogena - with the combined company expected to bring in annual revenues of roughly $32 billion.

The deal is expected to close in the second half of 2026.

content.title: Kimberly-Clark bets $40 billion on Kenvue despite Tylenol controversy
content.summary:
STORY: :: Kimberly-Clark

Kimberly-Clarke is betting big on the maker of Tylenol, announcing it will acquire parent company Kenvue for more than $40 billion... marking the largest buyout ever among the U.S. consumer goods industry.

The historic deal comes after U.S. President Donald Trump made remarks about the painkiller at the White House in September, citing unproven claims linking Tylenol use during pregnancy to autism in children.

:: September 22, 2025

UPSOUND US PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP: “Don't take Tylenol. Don't take it. If you just can't, I mean, fight like hell not to take it."

Shares of Tylenol-parent Kenvue - which also owns Band-Aid and Neutrogena - soared as much as 19% after the deal's announcement, while buyer Kimberly-Clark's shares tumbled about 14%.

:: File

Kenvue, which was spun off from Johnson & Johnson in 2023, has struggled for months with weak demand.

The company fired its CEO in July and said it was undergoing a strategic review of its assets.

Investor concern over Monday's merger announcement may stem in part from Kenvue's potential legal exposure to private lawsuits alleging it hid Tylenol's supposed link to autism in children.

U.S. sales of Tylenol fell 11% between September 20 and October 4 after Trump's remarks, according to a BNP Paribas analyst note last month.

:: Kimberly-Clark

But the merger does give Kimberly-Clark access to Kenvue's vast portfolio of brands - which also include Aveeno and Neutrogena - with the combined company expected to bring in annual revenues of roughly $32 billion.

The deal is expected to close in the second half of 2026.

headline: Why Kimberly-Clark (KMB) Stock Is Nosediving
summary: Shares of household products company Kimberly-Clark (NYSE:KMB) fell 12.6% in the afternoon session after it announced a deal to acquire consumer health company Kenvue Inc. in a cash and stock transaction valued at approximately $48.7 billion. The deal involved both cash and stock, which meant that the ownership stake for existing Kimberly-Clark shareholders was set to be diluted; they were expected to own about 54% of the combined company. The market's harsh reaction also seemed tied to Kenvue's

content.title: Why Kimberly-Clark (KMB) Stock Is Nosediving
content.summary: Shares of household products company Kimberly-Clark (NYSE:KMB) fell 12.6% in the afternoon session after it announced a deal to acquire consumer health company Kenvue Inc. in a cash and stock transaction valued at approximately $48.7 billion. The deal involved both cash and stock, which meant that the ownership stake for existing Kimberly-Clark shareholders was set to be diluted; they were expected to own about 54% of the combined company. The market's harsh reaction also seemed tied to Kenvue's

headline: Drug giant hit by Trump autism claims bought for record $49bn
summary: A US drug giant hit by Donald Trump’s claims linking its paracetamol brand to an increased risk of autism has been bought for $49bn (£37bn) after shares crashed to a record low.

content.title: Drug giant hit by Trump autism claims bought for record $49bn
content.summary: A US drug giant hit by Donald Trump’s claims linking its paracetamol brand to an increased risk of autism has been bought for $49bn (£37bn) after shares crashed to a record low.

headline: S&P 500, Nasdaq gain after Amazon-OpenAI deal; Kenvue soars after buyout
summary: 2025 -The S&P 500 and Nasdaq kicked off November on firmer ground on Monday, after a slew of AI deals boosted megacap companies Amazon and Nvidia, while Kenvue shares soared after Kimberly-Clark's buyout deal.  Amazon.com hit a record high after signing a multi-year $38 billion deal to supply cloud computing services to OpenAI, giving the ChatGPT maker access to Nvidia's graphics processors.  Nvidia gained 2.5% after President Donald Trump said the company's most advanced chips will be reserved for U.S. companies and Microsoft secured export licenses to use its chips in UAE data centers.

content.title: S&P 500, Nasdaq gain after Amazon-OpenAI deal; Kenvue soars after buyout
content.summary: 2025 -The S&P 500 and Nasdaq kicked off November on firmer ground on Monday, after a slew of AI deals boosted megacap companies Amazon and Nvidia, while Kenvue shares soared after Kimberly-Clark's buyout deal.  Amazon.com hit a record high after signing a multi-year $38 billion deal to supply cloud computing services to OpenAI, giving the ChatGPT maker access to Nvidia's graphics processors.  Nvidia gained 2.5% after President Donald Trump said the company's most advanced chips will be reserved for U.S. companies and Microsoft secured export licenses to use its chips in UAE data centers.

headline: Kimberly-Clark to buy Tylenol maker Kenvue, Iren & Microsoft deal
summary: There are a number of stocks on the move on Monday, Nov. 3. Kimberly-Clark (KMB) announced it is buying Kenvue (KVUE) in a deal valued at $48.7 billion. Iren (IREN) shares are soaring after striking a $9.7 billion deal with Microsoft (MSFT). Pfizer (PFE) is suing to block Novo Nordisk's (NVO) bid for obesity startup Metsera (MTSR). To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

headline: Kimberly-Clark Buying Tylenol Maker Kenvue in $40 Billion Deal
summary: Kimberly-Clark agreed to buy Kenvue in a deal worth roughly $40 billion in a combination that could create a company with $32 billion in revenue and allow it to surpass Unilever to become the second-biggest seller of health and wellness products after Procter & Gamble. Eric Pfanner reports on Bloomberg Television.

Eric Pfanner reports on Bloomberg Television.

headline: Berkshire earnings, Kimberly-Clark's deal to buy Tylenol maker
summary: US stock futures kick off November in the green as investors await earnings from Palantir (PLTR), AMD (AMD), and Qualcomm (QCOM) this week. Berkshire Hathaway (BRK-B, BRK-A) reported earnings over the weekend, with the company's cash pile reaching a record high of over $381 billion. Kimberly-Clark (KMB) will purchase Tylenol maker, Kenvue (KVUE), in a $40 billion deal. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

Berkshire Hathaway (BRK-B, BRK-A) reported earnings over the weekend, with the company's cash pile reaching a record high of over $381 billion.

Kimberly-Clark (KMB) will purchase Tylenol maker, Kenvue (KVUE), in a $40 billion deal.
